1.1.1.title: Non-text Content
1.1.1.description: All non-text content has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose
techniques: H37: Using alt attributes on img elements
H36: Using alt attributes on images used as submit buttons
H24: Providing text alternatives for the area elements of image maps
testing: Check all img elements have alt attributes
Verify decorative images have alt=""
Test complex images have detailed descriptions

1.2.1.title: Audio-only and Video-only (Prerecorded)
1.2.1.description: For prerecorded audio-only and video-only media, an alternative is provided
techniques: G158: Providing an alternative for time-based media for audio-only content
G159: Providing an alternative for time-based media for video-only content
testing: Check audio-only content has transcript
Verify video-only content has audio description or transcript

1.2.2.title: Captions (Prerecorded)
1.2.2.description: Captions are provided for all prerecorded audio content in synchronized media
techniques: G93: Providing open captions that can be viewed by everyone
G87: Providing closed captions
H95: Using the track element to provide captions
testing: Check videos have caption tracks
Verify captions are accurate and synchronized
Test caption quality and readability

1.3.1.title: Info and Relationships
1.3.1.description: Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined
techniques: H42: Using h1-h6 to identify headings
H43: Using id and headers attributes to associate data cells with header cells
H44: Using label elements to associate text labels with form controls
testing: Check heading hierarchy is logical
Verify form labels are properly associated
Test table headers are correctly marked up

1.3.2.title: Meaningful Sequence
1.3.2.description: When the sequence in which content is presented affects its meaning, a correct reading sequence can be programmatically determined
techniques: G57: Ordering the content in a meaningful sequence
C6: Positioning content based on structural markup
testing: Check reading order with CSS disabled
Verify tab order follows visual order
Test with screen reader to confirm sequence

1.3.3.title: Sensory Characteristics
1.3.3.description: Instructions provided for understanding and operating content do not rely solely on sensory characteristics
techniques: G96: Providing textual identification of items that otherwise rely only on sensory information
testing: Check instructions don't rely only on color
Verify position-based instructions have alternatives
Test with color blindness simulation

1.3.4.title: Orientation
1.3.4.description: Content does not restrict its view and operation to a single display orientation
techniques: F97: Failure due to locking the orientation to landscape or portrait view
testing: Test in both portrait and landscape
Verify all content remains accessible
Check no functionality is lost

1.3.5.title: Identify Input Purpose
1.3.5.description: The purpose of each input field collecting information about the user can be programmatically determined
techniques: H98: Using HTML 5.2 autocomplete attributes
testing: Check autocomplete attributes on form fields
Verify autocomplete values are appropriate
Test with password managers and form filling tools

1.4.1.title: Use of Color
1.4.1.description: Color is not used as the only visual means of conveying information
techniques: G14: Ensuring that information conveyed by color differences is also available in text
G111: Using color and pattern
G182: Ensuring that additional visual cues are available when text color differences are used
testing: Test with color blindness simulation
Check error states have icons or text
Verify links are distinguishable without color

1.4.2.title: Audio Control
1.4.2.description: If any audio plays automatically for more than 3 seconds, either a mechanism is available to pause or stop the audio, or a mechanism is available to control audio volume independently
techniques: G60: Playing a sound that turns off automatically within three seconds
G170: Providing a control near the beginning of the Web page that turns off sounds
testing: Check auto-playing audio has controls
Verify audio stops after 3 seconds or has pause button
Test volume controls work independently

1.4.3.title: Contrast (Minimum)
1.4.3.description: The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1
techniques: G18: Ensuring that a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1 exists between text and background
G145: Ensuring that a contrast ratio of at least 3:1 exists between text and background
testing: Check normal text meets 4.5:1 contrast ratio
Verify large text meets 3:1 contrast ratio
Test with color contrast analyzer tools

1.4.4.title: Resize Text
1.4.4.description: Except for captions and images of text, text can be resized without assistive technology up to 200 percent without loss of content or functionality
techniques: G142: Using a technology that has commonly-available user agents that support zoom
C28: Specifying the size of text containers using em units
testing: Test at 200% browser zoom
Verify no horizontal scrolling required
Check all content remains functional

1.4.5.title: Images of Text
1.4.5.description: If the technologies being used can achieve the visual presentation, text is used to convey information rather than images of text
techniques: C22: Using CSS to control visual presentation of text
C30: Using CSS to replace text with images of text
testing: Check for unnecessary images of text
Verify text can be customized by user
Test with custom stylesheets

1.4.10.title: Reflow
1.4.10.description: Content can be presented without loss of information or functionality, and without requiring scrolling in two dimensions
techniques: C32: Using media queries and grid CSS to reflow columns
C33: Allowing for Reflow with Long URLs and Strings of Text
testing: Test at 320px width equivalent to 400% zoom
Verify no two-dimensional scrolling required
Check content reflows properly

1.4.11.title: Non-text Contrast
1.4.11.description: The visual presentation of user interface components and graphical objects have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1 against adjacent colors
techniques: G195: Using an author-supplied, highly visible focus indicator
G207: Ensuring that a contrast ratio of 3:1 is provided for icons
testing: Check UI component contrast meets 3:1
Verify focus indicators meet contrast requirements
Test icons and graphics have adequate contrast

1.4.12.title: Text Spacing
1.4.12.description: In content implemented using markup languages that support the CSS properties, no loss of content or functionality occurs when text spacing is adjusted
techniques: C36: Allowing for text spacing override
C35: Allowing for text spacing without wrapping
testing: Test with increased line height (1.5x)
Test with increased letter spacing (0.12em)
Test with increased word spacing (0.16em)
Verify no content loss or overlap

1.4.13.title: Content on Hover or Focus
1.4.13.description: Where receiving and then removing pointer hover or keyboard focus triggers additional content to become visible and then hidden, the following are true: dismissible, hoverable, persistent
techniques: G207: Ensuring that a contrast ratio of 3:1 is provided for icons
testing: Test tooltip dismissal with Escape key
Verify hover content remains visible when hovering over it
Check content remains until hover/focus is removed

2.1.1.title: Keyboard
2.1.1.description: All functionality of the content is operable through a keyboard interface
techniques: G202: Ensuring keyboard control for all functionality
H91: Using HTML form controls and links
testing: Test all functionality with keyboard only
Verify custom controls respond to Enter and Space
Check arrow key navigation where appropriate

2.1.2.title: No Keyboard Trap
2.1.2.description: If keyboard focus can be moved to a component using a keyboard interface, then focus can be moved away from that component using only a keyboard interface
techniques: G21: Ensuring that users are not trapped in content
F10: Failure of Success Criterion 2.1.2 due to combining multiple content formats in a way that traps users inside one format type
testing: Test keyboard navigation throughout interface
Verify no keyboard focus traps exist
Check modal dialogs trap focus appropriately but allow escape

2.1.4.title: Character Key Shortcuts
2.1.4.description: If a keyboard shortcut is implemented using only letter, punctuation, number, or symbol characters, then at least one of the following is true: turn off, remap, active only on focus
techniques: G217: Providing a mechanism to allow users to remap or turn off character key shortcuts
testing: Check for single-key shortcuts
Verify shortcuts can be turned off
Test shortcuts don't interfere with typing

2.2.1.title: Timing Adjustable
2.2.1.description: For each time limit that is set by the content, the user can turn off, adjust, or extend the time limit
techniques: G133: Providing a checkbox on the first page of a multipart form
G198: Providing a way for the user to turn the time limit off
testing: Check for time limits in the interface
Verify users can extend or disable timeouts
Test session timeout warnings and extensions

2.2.2.title: Pause, Stop, Hide
2.2.2.description: For moving, blinking, scrolling, or auto-updating information, users can pause, stop, or hide it
techniques: G4: Allowing the content to be paused and restarted from where it was paused
G11: Creating content that blinks for less than 5 seconds
testing: Check for auto-playing content
Verify pause/stop controls are available
Test that content can be resumed from paused point

2.3.1.title: Three Flashes or Below Threshold
2.3.1.description: Web pages do not contain anything that flashes more than three times in any one second period
techniques: G19: Ensuring that no component of the content flashes more than three times in any 1-second period
testing: Check for flashing content
Verify flashing rate is below 3 times per second
Test with seizure sensitivity in mind

2.4.1.title: Bypass Blocks
2.4.1.description: A mechanism is available to bypass blocks of content that are repeated on multiple Web pages
techniques: G1: Adding a link at the top of each page that goes directly to the main content area
G123: Adding a link at the beginning of a block of repeated content to go to the end of the block
testing: Check for skip navigation links
Verify skip links work correctly
Test with screen reader navigation

2.4.2.title: Page Titled
2.4.2.description: Web pages have titles that describe topic or purpose
techniques: G88: Providing descriptive titles for Web pages
H25: Providing a title using the title element
testing: Check all pages have descriptive titles
Verify titles are unique and informative
Test titles help identify page content

2.4.3.title: Focus Order
2.4.3.description: If a Web page can be navigated sequentially and the navigation sequences affect meaning or operation, focusable components receive focus in an order that preserves meaning and operability
techniques: G59: Placing the interactive elements in an order that follows sequences and relationships within the content
C27: Making the DOM order match the visual order
testing: Test tab order follows visual layout
Verify focus order is logical
Check for focus order that skips important content

2.4.4.title: Link Purpose (In Context)
2.4.4.description: The purpose of each link can be determined from the link text alone or from the link text together with its programmatically determined link context
techniques: G91: Providing link text that describes the purpose of a link
H30: Providing link text that describes the purpose of a link for anchor elements
testing: Check link text is descriptive
Verify links make sense out of context
Test with screen reader link navigation

2.4.5.title: Multiple Ways
2.4.5.description: More than one way is available to locate a Web page within a set of Web pages except where the Web Page is the result of, or a step in, a process
techniques: G125: Providing links to navigate to related Web pages
G64: Providing a Table of Contents
G63: Providing a site map
testing: Check for multiple navigation methods
Verify search functionality exists
Test sitemap or navigation aids are present

2.4.6.title: Headings and Labels
2.4.6.description: Headings and labels describe topic or purpose
techniques: G130: Providing descriptive headings
G131: Providing descriptive labels
testing: Check headings are descriptive and informative
Verify form labels clearly describe purpose
Test headings help with navigation

2.4.7.title: Focus Visible
2.4.7.description: Any keyboard operable user interface has a mode of operation where the keyboard focus indicator is visible
techniques: G149: Using user interface components that are highlighted by the user agent when they receive focus
C15: Using CSS to change the presentation of a user interface component when it receives focus
testing: Test focus indicators are visible
Verify focus indicators meet contrast requirements
Check focus is clearly visible on all interactive elements

2.5.1.title: Pointer Gestures
2.5.1.description: All functionality that uses multipoint or path-based gestures for operation can be operated with a single pointer without a path-based gesture
techniques: G215: Providing controls to achieve the same result as path based or multipoint gestures
testing: Check for complex gestures
Verify single-pointer alternatives exist
Test with assistive technologies

2.5.2.title: Pointer Cancellation
2.5.2.description: For functionality that can be operated using a single pointer, completion of the function is on the up-event, and a mechanism is available to abort the function before completion or to undo the function after completion
techniques: G212: Using native controls to ensure functionality is triggered on the up-event
testing: Test click events trigger on mouse up
Verify touch events can be cancelled
Check accidental activations can be undone

2.5.3.title: Label in Name
2.5.3.description: For user interface components with labels that include text or images of text, the name contains the text that is presented visually
techniques: G208: Including the text of the visible label as part of the accessible name
testing: Check visible labels match accessible names
Verify speech input users can activate controls
Test with voice recognition software

2.5.4.title: Motion Actuation
2.5.4.description: Functionality that can be operated by device motion or user motion can also be operated by user interface components and responding to the motion can be disabled
techniques: G213: Provide conventional controls and an application setting for motion activated input
testing: Check for motion-triggered functionality
Verify conventional alternatives exist
Test motion can be disabled

3.1.1.title: Language of Page
3.1.1.description: The default human language of each Web page can be programmatically determined
techniques: H57: Using the language attribute on the HTML element
testing: Check html lang attribute is present
Verify language code is valid
Test with screen readers for proper pronunciation

3.1.2.title: Language of Parts
3.1.2.description: The human language of each passage or phrase in the content can be programmatically determined except for proper names, technical terms, words of indeterminate language, and words or phrases that have become part of the vernacular of the immediately surrounding text
techniques: H58: Using language attributes to identify changes in the human language
testing: Check foreign language content has lang attributes
Verify language changes are marked up
Test screen reader pronunciation

3.2.1.title: On Focus
3.2.1.description: When any user interface component receives focus, it does not initiate a change of context
techniques: G107: Using 'activate' rather than 'focus' as a trigger for changes of context
testing: Test focusing elements doesn't trigger navigation
Verify focus doesn't cause unexpected context changes
Check focus behavior is predictable

3.2.2.title: On Input
3.2.2.description: Changing the setting of any user interface component does not automatically cause a change of context unless the user has been advised of the behavior
techniques: G80: Providing a submit button to initiate a change of context
testing: Test form controls don't auto-submit
Verify input changes don't cause navigation
Check users are warned of automatic changes

3.2.3.title: Consistent Navigation
3.2.3.description: Navigational mechanisms that are repeated on multiple Web pages within a set of Web pages occur in the same relative order each time they are repeated
techniques: G61: Presenting repeated components in the same relative order each time they appear
testing: Check navigation appears in same order
Verify repeated elements are consistent
Test across multiple pages

3.2.4.title: Consistent Identification
3.2.4.description: Components that have the same functionality within a set of Web pages are identified consistently
techniques: G197: Using labels, names, and text alternatives consistently for content that has the same functionality
testing: Check similar components have consistent labels
Verify same functionality is identified consistently
Test across multiple pages

3.3.1.title: Error Identification
3.3.1.description: If an input error is automatically detected, the item that is in error is identified and the error is described to the user in text
techniques: G83: Providing text descriptions to identify required fields that were not completed
G85: Providing a text description when user input falls outside the required format or values
testing: Test form validation provides clear error messages
Verify errors identify specific fields
Check errors are associated with form controls

3.3.2.title: Labels or Instructions
3.3.2.description: Labels or instructions are provided when content requires user input
techniques: G131: Providing descriptive labels
G89: Providing expected data format and example
testing: Check all form fields have labels
Verify instructions are provided for complex inputs
Test required fields are clearly marked

3.3.3.title: Error Suggestion
3.3.3.description: If an input error is automatically detected and suggestions for correction are known, then the suggestions are provided to the user, unless it would jeopardize the security or purpose of the content
techniques: G177: Providing suggested correction text
G84: Providing a text description when the user provides information that is not in the list of allowed values
testing: Test error messages provide helpful suggestions
Verify corrections are offered when possible
Check suggestions don't compromise security

3.3.4.title: Error Prevention (Legal, Financial, Data)
3.3.4.description: For Web pages that cause legal commitments or financial transactions for the user to occur, that modify or delete user-controllable data in data storage systems, or that submit user test responses, at least one of the following is true: reversible, checked, confirmed
techniques: G98: Providing the ability for the user to review and correct answers before submitting
G155: Providing a checkbox in addition to a submit button
testing: Check important actions have confirmation steps
Verify destructive actions can be undone
Test data can be reviewed before submission

4.1.1.title: Parsing
4.1.1.description: In content implemented using markup languages, elements have complete start and end tags, elements are nested according to their specifications, elements do not contain duplicate attributes, and any IDs are unique
techniques: G134: Validating Web pages
H88: Using HTML according to spec
testing: Validate HTML markup
Check for duplicate IDs
Verify proper element nesting

4.1.2.title: Name, Role, Value
4.1.2.description: For all user interface components, the name and role can be programmatically determined; states, properties, and values that can be set by the user can be programmatically set
techniques: G108: Using markup features to expose the name and role, allow user-settable properties to be directly set, and provide notification of changes
H91: Using HTML form controls and links
testing: Check all UI components have accessible names
Verify roles are properly defined
Test states and properties are programmatically available

4.1.3.title: Status Messages
4.1.3.description: In content implemented using markup languages, status messages can be programmatically determined through role or properties such that they can be presented to the user by assistive technologies without receiving focus
techniques: G193: Providing help by an assistant in the Web page
ARIA22: Using role=status to present status messages
testing: Check status messages use appropriate ARIA roles
Verify messages are announced by screen readers
Test live regions work correctly
